timeline.bodyText: @ddsharpe, is there a bug for this?  Generally, I don't want to obscure problems by having the tests workaround something that doesn't work.
timeline.author: rjeberhard

replies.bodyText:
@rjeberhard it is not a known issue.  I just ran a quick test and do not see any issues.
./createDomain.sh -oracle_home ~/Oracle/Middleware12.2.1.3.0 -domain_parent . -model_file ~/Desktop/demo/my_domain.yaml -archive_file ~/Desktop/demo/my-domain.zip  -variable_file ~/Desktop/demo/my_domain1.10.properties
replies.author: ddsharpe

replies.bodyText:
I recall that before I changed "-" to "_" in the sourcePath in my model file, the following caused an error.
appDeployments:
Application:
myear:
SourcePath: wlsdeploy/applications/sample_app.ear
ModuleType: ear
Target: 'cluster-1'
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText:
Somehow WDT failed to parse the model yams file when the resourcePath contains "-". It seems that WDT considered -a as an option token and printed out this error:
####<Apr 10, 2020 6:00:40 PM>     <The WebLogic Deploy Tooling validateModel version is 1.7.2:master.10eaf6e:Mar 20, 2020 23:24 UTC>
line 31:53 token recognition error at: '-a'
####<Apr 10, 2020 6:00:40 PM>     <Parse error for file /u01/wdt/models/model1-wls.yaml at line 31 position 55: extraneous input 'pp.ear' expecting {COMMENT, NEWLINE}>
####<Apr 10, 2020 6:00:40 PM>   <__perform_model_file_validation>  <validateModel failed to load the model file /u01/wdt/models/model1-wls.yaml: Unable to parse model from file /u01/wdt/models/model1-wls.yaml : The YAML parser encountered 1 error(s) while parsing /u01/wdt/models/model1-wls.yaml>
####<Apr 10, 2020 6:00:40 PM>     <validateModel encountered an unexpected validation error: Unable to parse model from file /u01/wdt/models/model1-wls.yaml : The YAML parser encountered 1 error(s) while parsing /u01/wdt/models/model1-wls.yaml>
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText: We could handle this by converting "-" to "_" in the AppBuilder action, but it is easier just not to have "-" in the app name.
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText: Once I added "" around the value of sourcePath, the "-" in the application ear file path worked.
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText: This comment is still here :).  Let's change "sample_app" to use "sample-app" just to prove that it is fixed.
replies.author: rjeberhard

timeline.bodyText: It feels like the use of withAppParams() is disguising what is being built and tested.  I'll look below to see what this method does, but it's not clear what these statements do.
timeline.author: rjeberhard

replies.bodyText: withAppParams() method is a way of getting an instance of params without using the impl directly in the test code. The particular one just returns a new instance.
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText: Will it help if I add more explanation in the javadoc?
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText: this feels too magical - i assume it is setting some defaults, we should either not do that, or change the name to something like withDefaultAppParams() so it is clear what is happening
replies.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: I'll change the method name to defaultAppParams to be a little bit more clear. this method also hides things that a test writer does not need to know, for example, the version of the installers and etc. All parameters that a test writer cares need to be set once he/she gets an AppParams instance.
replies.author: doxiao

timeline.bodyText:
these are not accurate -- that closure is doing more than this
please make the descriptions as accurate as possible
timeline.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: good catch. fixed.
replies.author: doxiao

timeline.bodyText: include the exception in the fail message, so we know why it failed
timeline.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: applies to multiple places
replies.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: Changed the assertion to fail in two places.
replies.author: doxiao

timeline.bodyText: this feel like it could be a simple check and a throw IllegalArgsException - assertions are really for tests
timeline.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: done.
replies.author: doxiao

timeline.author: markxnelson

timeline.bodyText:
assertions are for tests, when implementing an action, i think we can just use the normal try/catch
@rjeberhard thoughts?
timeline.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: i don't like tests relying on assertions hidden away in actions/helper methods
replies.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: Agreed.  The test should deal with the exception.  Let "build()" throw it.
replies.author: ddsharpe

replies.bodyText: Removed all assertion in the actions.
replies.author: doxiao

timeline.bodyText: we have commons-io in the pom, so you could do this with just one call to FileUtils.deleteDirectory(file)
timeline.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: That is good to know. I'll change it.
replies.author: doxiao

timeline.bodyText: Same, throw an exception if something fails in an action (not a run-time exception, something that the test must catch)
timeline.author: ddsharpe

timeline.message:
Download and use apache commons-io to clean up a directory

Signed-off-by: doxiao <dongbo.xiao@oracle.com>

timeline.bodyText: um what is going on here? this is an infinite recursion?
timeline.author: markxnelson

replies.bodyText: hmm, I don't see recursiveness here. cleanDirectory is common-io FileUtils.cleanDirectory().  The method calls this is cleanupDirectory().
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText: And I tested the change:).
replies.author: doxiao

replies.bodyText: oh sorry, my bad -- those names were so close :)
replies.author: markxnelson
